case_name: Jaichand Lal Sethia v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 110 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION - Criminal Appeal No, 110 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 8, 1966 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 266 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION - Criminal Appeal No, 110 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 8, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Case No. 266 of 1965.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court refused to grant writ of habeas corpus on February 8, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, against the judgment of the Calcutta High Court dated February 8. 1966 in Criminal Misc. Case No. 266 of 1965 refusing to grant a writ in the nature of habeas companypus

facts.text: Appellant Jaichand Lal Sethia detained under order passed by Government of West Bengal under r. 30 of Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: ordering the release of the appellant, Jaichand Lal Sethia from detention under an order passed by the Government of West Bengal under r, 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Arguments in the appeal concluded on May 3, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: After the companyclusion of arguments in this case on May 3. 1966 we expressed the view that this appeal should be dismissed and the reasons will be stated later.

facts.text: Appellant carried on business of purchasing and selling goods like cloves, cinnamon, dye-stuff in Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant is that he was carrying on business of purchasing and selling goods like cloves, cinnamon, dye-stuff etc. in the city of Calcutta.

facts.text: In January 1963, appellant had trouble with police of Burrabazar P.S. in Calcutta, particularly Sub-Inspector Kalyan Dutt.

anchor.surface_text: In the month of January, 1963 the appellant had some trouble with the police of Burrabazar, P.S. in Calcutta, particularly with the Sub-Inspector Kalyan Dutt.

facts.text: Appellant incurred displeasure of Customs Department officers who seized his goods illegally and prevented participation in auction-sales.

anchor.surface_text: Officer-in-charge of that Police Station The appellant also said that he incurred the displeasure of the officers of the Customs De- partment who had illegally seized the goods of the appellant

facts.text: Appellant made complaint to higher authorities of Customs Department.

anchor.surface_text: and also prevented him from participating at the auction- sales of Customs Department. The appellant had made a companyplaint to the higher authorities of the Customs Department in this respect.

facts.text: Order of detention dated September 27, 1965 made by Government of West Bengal under r.30 Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: On September 27, 1965 the order of detention of the appellant was made by the Government of West Bengal under r. 30 of the Defence of India Rules and in pursuance of that order the appellant was detained

facts.text: Appellant detained in Presidency Jail at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: in the Presidency jail at Calcutta. The order of detention being No. 7422 H.S. of the Government of West Bengal Home Department Special Section reads as follows-

facts.text: Detention order No. 7422 H.S. by Governor of West Bengal, satisfied to prevent Jaichand Lal Sethia, son of Dipchand Sethia of 9 Decres Lane, Calcutta, from acting prejudicial to public order.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the Governor is satisfied that with a view to preventing Sri Jaichand Lal Sethia, son of Sri Dipchand Sethia of 9 Decres Lane, Calcutta from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of Public Order,

facts.text: Appellant obtained rule from Calcutta High Court for habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained a rule from the Calcutta High Court asking the respondents to show cause why a writ in the nature of habeas companypus should number be granted

facts.text: Appellant claimed detention order made mala fide due to personal hostility of police and Customs officers.

anchor.surface_text: directing the release of the appellant from detention. The case of the appellant was that the order of detention was made mala fide because the appellant had incurred the personal hostility of some officers

facts.text: On August 16, 1964, appellant sent representation to Chief Minister of West Bengal about police creating fictitious records.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out that on August 16, 1964 the appellant had sent a representation to the Chief Minister of West Bengal and other higher authorities saying that the police had been creating fictitious records

facts.text: In July 1965, three defamation cases started against appellant at instance of Customs officers.

anchor.surface_text: for putting the appellant under detention under the Defence of India Rules. In July, 1965 three defamation cases were started against the appellant at the instance of the Customs officers.

facts.text: In August and September 1965, appellant sent representations against police and Customs officers to Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: In August and September, 1965 the appellant had sent representations against the police and Customs officers to the Chief Minister, West Bengal and other higher authorities.

facts.text: Affidavit filed on behalf of State of West Bengal denying appellant's allegations.

anchor.surface_text: In response to the numberice an affidavit was filed on behalf of the State of West Bengal denying the allegations of the appellant.

facts.text: Affidavits filed by Kalyan Dutt and Debranjan Dutta controverting appellant's allegations.

anchor.surface_text: Affidavits were also filed by Kalyan Dutt and Debranjan Dutta companytroverting the allegations of the appellant so far as they were companycerned.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held order of detention lawfully made by Chief Minister, mala fide not established.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the parties, the Calcutta High Court hold that the order of detention was lawfully made by the Chief Minister of West Bengal and the allegation of mala fide had number been established by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, agreed with High Court that no mala fide established.

anchor.surface_text: On perusal of the various affidavits filed in the case the High Court reached the companyclusion that the allegation of mala fide made by the appellant had number been substantiated and the order of detention made by the Government of West Bengal companyld number be held to be legally invalid on this account. We see numberreason to take a view different from that of the High Court on this point.

facts.text: Mr. Sen Gupta, Deputy Secretary, stated Chief Minister did not consider criminal proceedings, was satisfied based on papers about appellant's illegal activities.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated by Mr. Sen Gupta that in making the order of detention dated September 27, 1965 the Chief Minister, West Bengal did number take into companysideration the criminal proceedings pending against the appellant before the Police and Customs authorities.

facts.text: Kalyan Dutt denied creating fictitious records or recommending detention.

anchor.surface_text: The allegation of the appellant has also been denied by Kalyan Dutt in his affidavit. Mr. Kalyan Dutt states that he never created fictitious records against the appellant and never prepared or forwarded any history-sheet

facts.text: Appellant engaged in procuring and selling goods illegally and clandestinely.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen Gupta further said that all papers available to State Government as to the activities of the appellant Jaichand Lal Sethia were placed before the Chief Minister who was personally satisfied that the appellant was engaged in illegal activities prejudicial to the maintenance of public order

facts.text: Proclamation of Emergency issued by President on October 26, 1962.

issues.text: Whether the order of detention was made mala fide because the appellant had incurred the personal hostility of some officers in the police and Customs Departments and was based on false reports by them

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that the order of detention was made mala fide because the appellant had incurred the personal hostility of some officers in the police and Customs Departments. It was contended that the order of detention was procured mala fide upon false reports made vindictively under the Defence of India Rules by the officers in the police and Customs Departments.

issues.text: Whether challenges to the validity of the detention order on grounds other than contravention of Articles 14, 19, 21 and 22, such as mala fides, are barred by the Presidential Orders issued under Article 359 during the Emergency

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the appellant it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab and in Durgadas Shirali v. The Union of India and Anr. this Court had occasion to consider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the Presidentone dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers conferred by cl. 1 of Art. 359 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the court can inquire into the subjective satisfaction of the detaining authority, including the sufficiency of material or grounds for the order of detention under r.30 of the Defence of India Rules

anchor.surface_text: The satisfaction of the Government which justifies the order of detention under r. 30 is a subjective satisfaction. A court cannot normally enquire whether grounds existed which would have created that satisfaction on which alone the order could have been made in the mind of a reasonable person.

issues.text: Whether the High Court should have directed production of the departmental file or affidavit from the Chief Minister to verify the application of mind and accuracy of the detention order recital

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended on behalf of the appellant that the High Court should have called upon the State Government to produce the file concerning detention of the appellant in order to determine for itself whether the Chief Minister had sufficient material before him for satisfying himself as to the necessity for the detention of the appellant.

issues.text: Whether the affidavit filed by the Deputy Secretary on behalf of the State Government was sufficient to controvert the allegations of mala fides, or whether an affidavit from the Chief Minister was necessary

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the appellant it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab and in Durgadas Shirali v. The Union of India and Anr. this Court had occasion to consider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962

arguments.claim: Satisfaction under r.30 is subjective; court cannot inquire into sufficiency of grounds normally
Presumption omnia rite acta applies to authenticated detention order recital

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the well-known presumption omnia esse rite acta applies to this order, and, accordingly, assuming the order to be proved or admitted, it must be taken prima facie, that is until the contrary is proved, to have been properly made

arguments.claim: No need to produce file or affidavit from Chief Minister absent lacuna or mala fides allegation against him
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes Biren Dutta and Jagannath Misra cases due to different facts

arguments.claim: Affidavit by Deputy Secretary sufficient to controvert allegations where no mala fides against Chief Minister
High Court justified in not ordering discovery/production of departmental file
arguments.court_reasoning: Facts differ from precedents cited by petitioner

holdings.text: The allegation of mala fide made by the appellant had not been substantiated and the order of detention made by the Government of West Bengal could not be held to be legally invalid on this account

anchor.surface_text: On perusal of the various affidavits filed in the case the High Court reached the conclusion that the allegation of mala fide made by the appellant had not been substantiated and the order of detention made by the Government of West Bengal could not be held to be legally invalid on this account. We see no reason to take a view different from that of the High Court on this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Perusal of affidavits by Sen Gupta, Kalyan Dutt, Debaranjan Dutta denying allegations; High Court conclusion agreed with by Supreme Court

holdings.text: A citizen will not be deprived of the right to move an appropriate Court for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide

anchor.surface_text: Such a challenge is outside the purview of the Presidential Order. For instance, a citizen will not be deprived of the right to move an appropriate Court for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide. Similarly, it will be open to the citizen to challenge the order of detention on the ground that any of the grounds given in the order of detention is irrelevant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Makhan Singh Tarsikka and Durgadas Shirali; Presidential Order under Art.359 bars only claims enforcing Arts.14,19,21,22 but not other grounds like mala fides

holdings.text: The satisfaction of the Government which justifies the order of detention under r. 30 is a subjective satisfaction. A court cannot normally enquire whether grounds existed which would have created that satisfaction

anchor.surface_text: The satisfaction of the Government which justifies the order of detention under r. 30 is a subjective satisfaction. A court cannot normally enquire whether grounds existed which would have created that satisfaction on which alone the order could have been made in the mind of a reasonable person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subjective satisfaction doctrine; if order regular on face, no inquiry into sufficiency unless mala fides or no application of mind; cites Shibnath Banerjee, Liversidge, Greene

holdings.text: the well-known presumption omnia esse rite acta applies to this order, and, accordingly, assuming the order to be proved or admitted, it must be taken prima facie, that is until the contrary is proved, to have been properly made

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the well-known presumption omnia esse rite acta applies to this order, and, accordingly, assuming the order to be proved or admitted, it must be taken prima facie, that is until the contrary is proved, to have been properly made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Presumption of regularity for authenticated official acts like detention order recital of satisfaction; burden on detenu to disprove

holdings.text: the High Court was justified in not making an order for discovery or production of the original departmental file containing the activities of the appellant by the Government of West Bengal
holdings.reasoning_summary: No lacuna in order; distinguishes Biren Dutta and Jagannath Misra on facts (no allegation of non-compliance with r.30A or ambiguous order); file production only if lacuna, mala fides against authority, or no mind applied

holdings.text: There is no allegation made by the appellant that the Chief Minister himself was acting mala fide ... it was not necessary for the High Court to call for an affidavit from the Chief Minister and the affidavit filed by Mr. Sen Gupta on behalf of the Government of West Bengal was rightly considered by the High Court as sufficient
holdings.reasoning_summary: No mala fides alleged against Chief Minister (detaining authority); Deputy Secretary affidavit adequate to deny subordinate officers' mala fides

precedents.citation: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  and in Durgadas Shirali v. The Union of India and Anr.  2  this Court had occasion to companysider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the Presidentone dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President and Presidential Orders under Art. 359 of the Constitution, scope wide enough to include claims enforcing fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22; validity of orders cannot be questioned on grounds of contravening Arts. 14, 21, 22 but can on other grounds
precedents.cited_holding: the scope of Art. 359(1) and the Presidential Order issued under it is wide enough to include all claims made by citizens in any Court of competent Jurisdiction when it is shown that the said claims cannot be effectively adjudicated upon without examining the question as to whether the citizen is, in substance, seeking to enforce fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22

precedents.citation: Durgadas Shirali v. The Union of India and Anr.  2

anchor.surface_text: Durgadas Shirali v. The Union of India and Anr.  2  this Court had occasion to companysider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the Presidentone dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution. It was held by this Court that the scope of Art. 359 1

precedents.case_name: Durgadas Shirali v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency and Presidential Orders under Art. 359

anchor.surface_text: King Emperor v. Shibnath Banerjee 1  as follows- It is quite a different thing to question the accuracy of a recital contained in a duly authenticated order, particularly w here the recital purports to state as a fact the carrying out of what I regard as a condition necessary to the valid making of that order.

precedents.cited_proposition: legal position on challenging recital of satisfaction in detention order; court accepts recital in absence of evidence of inaccuracy; difficult burden on detenu
precedents.cited_holding: It is quite a different thing to question the accuracy of a recital contained in a duly authenticated order, particularly where the recital purports to state as a fact the carrying out of what I regard as a condition necessary to the valid making of that order. In the normal case the existence of such a recital in a duly authenticated order will, in the absence of any evidence as to its inaccuracy, be accepted by a court as establishing that the necessary condition was fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: Liversidge V. Sir John Anderson 2  and Greene v. Secretary of State for Home Affairs  3 . The question in those cases was whether the Home Secretary had reasonable cause to believe that certain persons were of hostile associations and that by reason thereof it was necessary to exercise control over them.

precedents.cited_proposition: court not entitled to investigate grounds of executive's subjective satisfaction or belief in detention matters

precedents.citation: Greene v. Secretary of State for Home Affairs  3

anchor.surface_text: Greene v. Secretary of State for Home Affairs  3 . The question in those cases was whether the Home Secretary had reasonable cause to believe that certain persons were of hostile associations and that by reason thereof it was necessary to exercise control over them. It was held that the matter was one for the executive discretion of the Secretary of State,

precedents.case_name: Greene v Secretary of State for Home Affairs
precedents.cited_proposition: where valid order produced, burden on prisoner to prove facts controverting it; no need for affidavit unless specific grounds raised
precedents.cited_holding: I am of opinion that where on the return an order or warrant which is valid on its face is produced it is for the prisoner to prove the facts necessary to controvert it... that does not require an answer because it in no way shows that the Secretary of State had no reasonable cause to believe, or did not believe, otherwise.

precedents.citation: Biren Dutta etc. v. Chief Commissioner of Tripura

anchor.surface_text: Biren Dutta etc. v. Chief Commissioner of Tripura this Court made an order directing the Chief Secretary to the Tripura Administration to transmit to this Court the original files in respect of the detenus and also directed the Minister concerned or the Secretary or the Administrator to file an affidavit in this Court stating all the material facts indicating whether the decision arrived at was duly communicated to the detenus concerned.

precedents.case_name: Biren Dutta v Chief Commissioner of Tripura
precedents.cited_proposition: court directed production of files and affidavit where allegation that order of review not reduced to writing, conditions not complied with, not communicated

precedents.citation: Jagannath Misra The State of Orissa 1

anchor.surface_text: Jagannath Misra The State of Orissa 1 -in which this Court ordered the Home Minister to file an affidavit. In that case the order of detention was defective because the authenticated copy of the order mentioned six grounds with the disjunctive or mentioned in the affidavit of the Chief Secretary. Some of these grounds were followed by etc In view of the ambiguity of the order this Court made a direction asking the State Government to produce the original order which was in the form of a document and also called for an affidavit from the Home Minister who was in-charge of matters of detention.

precedents.case_name: Jagannath Misra v State of Orissa
precedents.cited_proposition: court ordered affidavit from Home Minister where detention order defective/ambiguous (grounds with 'or', 'etc.')

anchor.surface_text: On perusal of the various affidavits filed in the case the High Court reached the conclusion that the allegation of mala fide made by the appellant had not been substantiated and the order of detention made by the Government of West Bengal could not be held to be legally invalid on this account. We see no reason to take a view different from that of the High Court on this point.
After the companyclusion of arguments in this case on May 3. 1966 we expressed the view that this appeal should be dismissed and the reasons will be stated later.
, 21 and 22. It was pointed out that during the pendency of the Presidential Order the validity of the Ordinance or any rule or order made thereunder

edges.explanation: Holding resolves the issue by affirming right to challenge on mala fides despite Art.359

anchor.surface_text: Such a challenge is outside the purview of the Presidential Order. For instance, a citizen will not be deprived of the right to move an appropriate Court for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide. Similarly, it will be open to the citizen to challenge the order of detention on the ground that any of the grounds given in the order of detention is irrelevant
After the companyclusion of arguments in this case on May 3. 1966 we expressed the view that this appeal should be dismissed and the reasons will be stated later.

anchor.surface_text: The satisfaction of the Government which justifies the order of detention under r. 30 is a subjective satisfaction. A court cannot normally enquire whether grounds existed which would have created that satisfaction on which alone the order could have been made in the mind of a reasonable person.
